awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of an Illumina MiSeq Sequencing System to enhance environmental research in the Great Lakes region
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to support the acquisition of a next-generation sequencing System for Grand Valley State University's Annis Water Resources Institute (AWRI). High-throughput sequencing data is now incorporated into all areas of biology, from medical research to environmental sciences.  AWRI is a research unit within Grand Valley State University that focuses on improving and enhancing freshwater resources. Sequencing system at AWRI will provide opportunity to directly train graduate and undergraduate students in this critical technology. AWRI's commitment to improving and preserving water resources also has broad societal benefit because of the basic research, public health and environmental relevance of understanding essential water resources. AWRI also engages in regional educational outreach program for K-12 students, universities, and the general public

Key projects that will be conducted by AWRI faculty and students through the acquisition of the sequencing system include: assessment of how invasive species alter mycorrhizal communities of native species in coastal sand dune systems; characterization of microbial communities associated with harmful algal blooms (HABs) across freshwater lakes ascribed to different trophic scales; evaluation of the relationship between invasive species introduction and changes in viral communities in the Great Lakes; and characterization of microbial communities associated with plastic pollution in freshwater lakes.  Collectively, these projects will provide vital information regarding how some of the most significant environmental challenges of our time are driving changes in the Great Lakes, which comprises nearly 20% of the world's supply of freshwater. Furthermore, each project contributes to our understanding of how anthropogenic-related habitat degradation drives community level changes within ecosystems, which can be applicable not only for the Great Lakes region but for ecosystems throughout the world.  Results from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research projects that have been enabled by acquisition of Illumina MiSeq system from 2018 - 2021 include: (1) assessing the bacterial community composition associated with microplastics in Muskegon Lake, MI, (2) examining how 'muck pellets' alter the soil microbial communities in freshwater lakes and ponds, (3) evaluating the dietary composition of Massasauga rattlesnakes, (4) evaluating the dietary composition of little brown bats, (5) examining how the ingestion of microplastics alters the natural gut microbial community of fathead minnows, and (6) comparing epiphyte fauna on native aquatic plants in the presence and absence of invasive starry stonewort. Thus far, the project has resulted in two publications in The Journal of Great Lakes Research and Lake and Reservoir Management, and two additional publications are in preparation.

The first published project evaluated microbial communities associated with microplastic pollution within various areas of an environmentally impacted lake. Muskegon Lake is a drowned-river mouth lake connected to Lake Michigan, and is an Area of Concern (AOC) based upon the legacy of pollutants within the system. While significant efforts have been made to restore the health of Muskegon Lake, new environmental stressors, such as the accumulation of microplastics may further challenge the health of this system. We characterized the bacterial community composition associated with different plastic polymers (polyethylene, polypropylene, and polyester) that were incubated in Muskegon Lake, MI. This consisted of creating amplicon libraries and sequencing 54 microplastic samples that were incubated in different areas of Muskegon Lake and at different depths. We found that while there was some variation among these polymer types, the primary factor driving bacterial colonization on microplastics was their location within the lake. We also found that polyester microplastics had a higher number of bacterial families than the other polymer types, and that the relative abundance of the bacterial families were more evenly distributed on the polyester microplastics. This work also showed that polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) pollutants tended to concentrate more on polyethylene microplastics than the other polymer types; however, these levels were still below the probable effect concentration. We are currently exploring how these increased concentrations of organic pollutants, along with the associated bacterial communities, impact the health of aquatic wildlife that ingest these particles.

The project associated with the second publication is a collaborative project to evaluate the microbial content of commercially available 'muck pellets' and to assess how the use of these muck pellets alter the soil microbial community when used in lakes and ponds. Muck pellets are sold as beneficial bacteria and enzymes that work to remove top layer organic material (i.e. muck) from lakes and ponds. This is an important topic as the pellets are often marketed to lake associations, but their effects on organic matter build-up and how they may alter the native microbial communities within lakes and ponds is unknown. Soil samples were collected from three Michigan lakes and incubated in the lab under different environmental conditions. These conditions included two different temperatures (ambient and 3+), two oxygen conditions (oxic and anoxic), and either in the presence or absence of a commercially available muck pellet. Soil samples were collected for sequencing both prior to initial treatment and then 8-weeks into the experiment. Samples were amplified using PCR for the 16S rRNA v4 region. Sample libraries were pooled and the amplicons were sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq System. We found that the main bacterial composition of the muck pellet was Bacillaceae. We also found that there were no significant differences in the soil bacterial communities between samples incubated with muck pellets and those incubated without for any of the three lakes tested. Similarly, the addition of the muck pellets had no significant effect on the percent organic matter or on absolute organic matter for any of the lakes tested.

In terms of broader impacts, the acquisition of the sequencer has enabled three Master's theses, and four undergraduate research projects. Research students on these projects have been trained in a combination of sequencing library preparation, library quality assurance, sequencer maintenance, and data processing. The presence of this instrument has also allowed us to incorporate more raw sequencing data into graduate and undergraduate classes. Some of the past and future planned projects that have been enabled also include collaborative work between our institute, local lake management association groups, and local tribal groups. We are continuing to increase our user base by forming collaborative projects with individuals from local community colleges (such as Muskegon Community College) and other primary undergraduate institutes in the area.
